ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to write essays without a clear prompt or format as well as to be more confident in class.
How to think about different art historical models.
I thought it was a very good course at cohesively looking at art history.
I learned about the history of art history and theory/philosophy about art

This course exposes students to foundational texts in the discipline of art history and encourages them to think critically about their contributions to the field. If you've spent extensive time in the department, it's likely that you've been exposed (at a surface level) to some content, though expect to leave with additional conversational depth.

I appreciated being able to think in a more big-picture way about the field of art history and the models we use when analyzing works of art. The most helpful skills and insights were theoretical, being able to choose which theoretical frameworks to apply, and recognizing the benefits and drawbacks of any choice.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I felt lost a lot of the time, and unsure about how to participate in class at times.  Professor Armstrong is a very kind person, but the coursework was challenging and I never felt 100% confident in my abilities.  That said, I think this course made me a much stronger writer and also taught me to think about art from different views and effectively argue points.
Overall good, discussion-based course. Professor Armstrong led engaging discussions and asked challenging questions that pushed us to engage further with the course materials and readings.
I think the course could have more resources for students and more guidance for how to read through sources.
There was a lot of reading- discussion was sometimes helpful but didnt tend to clarify topics as much as one would hope

Weakness: I think the class could facilitate much better discussions and learning if the reading selections were chosen differently. As it stands, readings work like this: 

Ex: week on feminist art history 
Readings: different feminist art historians and their opinions on how/why to do it, etc. 
Discussions: what does author 1 say? What does author 2 say? What do you think? 

The class would be much better if it were instead like this: 
Ex: week on feminist history 
Readings: ONE authors approach at feminist art history, supplemented with essays by other art historians applying author Xs specific method. 
Discussions: whose argument was most compelling? Why? How did they do it? 

In the second case, the class would be able to discuss their opinions on the application of theory, rather than the theory itself, which unfortunately led to quite stale discussions. Of course, it comes with the caveat of exposing us to less perspectives, but I think its preferable because wed understand one perspective far more tangibly.
There is a lot of reading (too much), but Professor Armstrong was helpful and told us which readings to prioritize.

This course benefits from its small size, and I'd encourage that the department host two concurrent Critical Approaches seminars to facilitate additional conversation. I appreciated also the extensive feedback received though would have preferred it be delivered via email or canvas. In appreciation for the tremendous effort invested in curating a syllabus, I wonder if students would appreciate deciding amongst themselves which "model" to consider for a given week later in the semester (perhaps from among 2-3 options).

I didn't always understand why we were doing a particular reading as opposed to others. It was also sometimes frustrating in that it didn't feel like we came to any conclusions or made any significant headway, though this might be unavoidable given the topic and scope.

I liked the format of the position papers and Professor Armstrong gave clear and thorough feedback that pushed my thinking. I also appreciated that she ranked the readings in order of importance so that we knew what to prioritize.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes!

Yes, if you are a History of Art major or love philosophy (and you know what you're doing  this is not an easy class).  The class is very writing intensive and thought-provoking; while I ended up liking it, it was very stressful, and I honestly have no idea how I did on the final essay.
Yes, recommend for art history majors.
Its mandatory for the major.
Its required
Yes.
Its a required course, so I guess I would recommend for art history majors if they want to graduate

If you are not an art history major, I'd think twice about taking the course (both in an effort to save space for department majors and in an admission of the course's difficulty). If you're a major, I'd recommend sitting for the course during a semester in which you don't anticipate a high workload.
Yes I think that it is a helpful course, particularly for History of Art majors
